channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Signatures of Fractional Quantum Anomalous Hall States in Twisted MoTe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06289-w

Signatures of Fractional Quantum Anomalous Hall States in Twisted MoTe2
item.dc:title: Signatures of Fractional Quantum Anomalous Hall States in Twisted MoTe<sub>2</sub>

item.title: Prized dinosaur fossil returned to Brazil after controversy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01969-z

The one-of-a-kind specimen will be housed at a museum in Santana do Cariri, near where it was found.
item.dc:title: Prized dinosaur fossil returned to Brazil after controversy
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: What IBM’s result means for quantum computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01966-2

A test case for practical applications of quantum computers, and how psychedelic drugs might make brains more malleable.
item.dc:title: What IBM’s result means for quantum computing
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Single-photon absorption and emission from a natural photosynthetic complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06121-5

Using a heralded single-photon source along with coincidence counting, we establish time correlation functions for B800 excitation and B850 fluorescence emission and demonstrate that both events involve single photons.
item.dc:title: Single-photon absorption and emission from a natural photosynthetic complex
item.dc:creator: Quanwei Li
Kaydren Orcutt
Robert L. Cook
Javier Sabines-Chesterking
Ashley L. Tong
Gabriela S. Schlau-Cohen
Xiang Zhang
Graham R. Fleming
K. Birgitta Whaley

item.title: General cross-coupling reactions with adaptive dynamic homogeneous catalysis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06087-4

A self-adjustive catalytic system with nickel under visible-light-driven redox reaction conditions provides a general method for carbon–(hetero)atom cross-coupling reactions and is demonstrated for nine different bond-forming reactions.
item.dc:title: General cross-coupling reactions with adaptive dynamic homogeneous catalysis
item.dc:creator: Indrajit Ghosh
Nikita Shlapakov
Tobias A. Karl
Jonas Düker
Maksim Nikitin
Julia V. Burykina
Valentine P. Ananikov
Burkhard König

item.title: Non-orientable order and non-commutative response in frustrated metamaterials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06022-7

We describe globally frustrated matter as deformations of non-orientable surfaces, with the concept of non-orientable order we demonstrate topologically protected mechanical memories, suggesting a design principle for effectively storing information in frustrated metamaterials.
item.dc:title: Non-orientable order and non-commutative response in frustrated metamaterials
item.dc:creator: Xiaofei Guo
Marcelo Guzmán
David Carpentier
Denis Bartolo
Corentin Coulais

item.title: Krill body size drives particulate organic carbon export in West Antarctica
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06041-4

A multi-decadal sediment-trap time series reveals that the body size, not the abundance, of Antarctic krill drives the particulate organic carbon flux on the continental shelf of the West Antarctic Peninsula.
item.dc:title: Krill body size drives particulate organic carbon export in West Antarctica
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Trinh
Hugh W. Ducklow
Deborah K. Steinberg
William R. Fraser

item.title: A pangenome reference of 36 Chinese populations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06173-7

A study reports data from the first phase of the Chinese Pangenome Consortium including 116 de novo assemblies from 58 core samples representing 36 minority Chinese ethnic groups.
item.dc:title: A pangenome reference of 36 Chinese populations

item.title: Excitonic topological order in imbalanced electron–hole bilayers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06065-w

This study reports an excitonic topological order emerging in imbalanced electron–hole bilayers.
item.dc:title: Excitonic topological order in imbalanced electron–hole bilayers
item.dc:creator: Rui Wang
Tigran A. Sedrakyan
Baigeng Wang
Lingjie Du
Rui-Rui Du

item.title: A tripartite rheostat controls self-regulated host plant resistance to insects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06197-z

Insect salivary protein (BISP) targets OsRLCK185 to suppress defence in susceptible plants, whereas in resistant plants BISP binds BPH14 to activate host plant resistance. To restore cellular homeostasis, the resistance mechanism is fine-tuned by selective autophagy.
item.dc:title: A tripartite rheostat controls self-regulated host plant resistance to insects
item.dc:creator: Jianping Guo

item.title: Psychedelics reopen the social reward learning critical period
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06204-3

Behavioural electrophysiological and transcriptomic studies in mice show that psychedelic drugs reopen the social reward learning critical period and suggest that this involves reorganization of the extracellular matrix.
item.dc:title: Psychedelics reopen the social reward learning critical period
item.dc:creator: Romain Nardou
Edward Sawyer
Young Jun Song
Makenzie Wilkinson
Yasmin Padovan-Hernandez
Júnia Lara de Deus

Gül Dölen

item.title: The neuroscience of cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05968-y

This Review examines the interplay between the nervous system and tumours, from cancer initiation to progression and metastasis.
item.dc:title: The neuroscience of cancer
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Mancusi
Michelle Monje

item.title: Evidence for the utility of quantum computing before fault tolerance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06096-3

Experiments on a noisy 127-qubit superconducting quantum processor report the accurate measurement of expectation values beyond the reach of current brute-force classical computation, demonstrating evidence for the utility of quantum computing before fault tolerance.
item.dc:title: Evidence for the utility of quantum computing before fault tolerance
item.dc:creator: Youngseok Kim
Andrew Eddins
Sajant Anand
Ken Xuan Wei
Ewout van den Berg
Sami Rosenblatt
Hasan Nayfeh
Yantao Wu
Michael Zaletel
Kristan Temme
Abhinav Kandala

item.title: Spin state and deep interior structure of Mars from InSight radio tracking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06150-0

Analysis of radio science data from the NASA InSight Mars lander reveals details of the rotation of the planet, which have been used to determine fundamental information about its core, mantle and atmosphere.
item.dc:title: Spin state and deep interior structure of Mars from InSight radio tracking
item.dc:creator: Sébastien Le Maistre
Attilio Rivoldini
Alfonso Caldiero

W. Bruce Banerdt

item.title: Mitotic tethering enables inheritance of shattered micronuclear chromosomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06216-z

Chromothriptically produced pieces of a micronucleated chromosome are shown to be tethered together in mitosis by a protein complex consisting of MDC1, TOPBP1 and CIP2A, thus enabling their inheritance by a single daughter cell.
item.dc:title: Mitotic tethering enables inheritance of shattered micronuclear chromosomes
item.dc:creator: Prasad Trivedi
Christopher D. Steele
Franco K. C. Au
Ludmil B. Alexandrov
Don W. Cleveland

item.title: Detection of phosphates originating from Enceladus’s ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05987-9

Cassini’s Cosmic Dust Analyzer mass spectra of ice grains emitted by Enceladus show the presence of sodium phosphates, suggesting that phosphorus is readily available in Enceladus’s ocean in the form of orthophosphates.
item.dc:title: Detection of phosphates originating from Enceladus’s ocean
item.dc:creator: Frank Postberg
Yasuhito Sekine
Fabian Klenner
Christopher R. Glein
Zenghui Zou
Bernd Abel

item.title: Vanadium oxide and a sharp onset of cold-trapping on a giant exoplanet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06134-0

Analysis of transits of an ultra-hot giant exoplanet reports the precise abundance constraints of 14 major refractory elements, showing distinct deviations from proto-solar, along with a sharp transition temperature at which those elements are depleted.
item.dc:title: Vanadium oxide and a sharp onset of cold-trapping on a giant exoplanet
item.dc:creator: Stefan Pelletier
Björn Benneke
Mohamad Ali-Dib

Julian Stürmer

item.title: Inference and reconstruction of the heimdallarchaeial ancestry of eukaryotes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06186-2

Analyses of multiple phylogenetic marker datasets of Asgard archaea provide insight into the transition from prokaryotes to eukaryotes, specifically placing eukaryotes within Asgard archaea and as a sister lineage to Hodarchaeales.
item.dc:title: Inference and reconstruction of the heimdallarchaeial ancestry of eukaryotes
item.dc:creator: Laura Eme
Daniel Tamarit

item.title: Genome editing of a rice CDP-DAG synthase confers multipathogen resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06205-2

Editing of a rice gene that has a role in phospholipid synthesis has endowed rice plants with broad-spectrum resistance to disease, including protection from common bacterial and fungal pathogens, without decreasing the yield.
item.dc:title: Genome editing of a rice CDP-DAG synthase confers multipathogen resistance
item.dc:creator: Gan Sha
Peng Sun

item.title: Liquid metal for high-entropy alloy nanoparticles synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06082-9

We discovered that liquid metal endowing negative mixing enthalpy with other elements could provide a stable thermodynamic condition and act as a desirable dynamic mixing reservoir, realizing the synthesis of high-entropy alloy nanoparticles.
item.dc:title: Liquid metal for high-entropy alloy nanoparticles synthesis
item.dc:creator: Guanghui Cao
Jingjing Liang
Zenglong Guo

item.title: High-brightness scalable continuous-wave single-mode photonic-crystal laser
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06059-8

We developed large-scale photonic-crystal surface-emitting lasers with controlled Hermitian and non-Hermitian couplings inside the photonic crystal and a pre-installed spatial distribution of the lattice constant, which leads to the realization of a continuous-wave brightness of 1 GW cm−2 sr−1.
item.dc:title: High-brightness scalable continuous-wave single-mode photonic-crystal laser
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Yoshida
Shumpei Katsuno
Takuya Inoue
John Gelleta
Koki Izumi
Menaka De Zoysa
Kenji Ishizaki
Susumu Noda

item.title: Break-induced replication orchestrates resection-dependent template switching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06177-3

Break-induced telomere synthesis initiates recruitment of the SNM1A nuclease, which promotes DNA end resection that in turn allows template switching to enable bypass of lesions.
item.dc:title: Break-induced replication orchestrates resection-dependent template switching
item.dc:creator: Tianpeng Zhang
Yashpal Rawal
Haoyang Jiang
Youngho Kwon
Patrick Sung
Roger A. Greenberg

item.title: Genetic stabilization of attenuated oral vaccines against poliovirus types 1 and 3
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06212-3

Mouse experiments and deep sequencing confirmed that two additional live attenuated vaccine candidates against type 1 and 3 polioviruses remained attenuated and preserved all documented nOPV2 characteristics concerning genetic stability following accelerated virus evolution.
item.dc:title: Genetic stabilization of attenuated oral vaccines against poliovirus types 1 and 3
item.dc:creator: Ming Te Yeh
Matthew Smith
Sarah Carlyle
Jennifer L. Konopka-Anstadt
Cara C. Burns
John Konz
Raul Andino
Andrew Macadam

item.title: Dedicated macrophages organize and maintain the enteric nervous system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06200-7

Resident macrophages of the muscularis externa refine the enteric nervous system (ENS) early in life by pruning synapses and phagocytosing enteric neurons, and later switch to a neuro-supportive function, indicating that the ENS is governed by a dedicated population of resident macrophages that adapt to the timely needs of the ENS.
item.dc:title: Dedicated macrophages organize and maintain the enteric nervous system
item.dc:creator: Maria Francesca Viola
Marta Chavero-Pieres
Elodie Modave

item.title: Hadaean to Palaeoarchaean stagnant-lid tectonics revealed by zircon magnetism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06024-5

Magnetic palaeointensity data from the Barberton Greenstone Belt (South Africa) as well as the Jack Hills (Western Australia) show nearly constant palaeofield values between 3.9 Ga and 3.4 Ga, providing evidence for stagnant-lid mantle convection.
item.dc:title: Hadaean to Palaeoarchaean stagnant-lid tectonics revealed by zircon magnetism
item.dc:creator: John A. Tarduno

item.title: CD4<sup>+</sup> T cell-induced inflammatory cell death controls immune-evasive tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06199-x

This article describes a mechanism through which CD4+ T cells can eradicate MHC-deficient tumours that escape direct CD8+ T cell targeting and thereby complement the activity of CD8+ T cells and natural killer cells to advance cancer immunotherapies.
item.dc:title: CD4<sup>+</sup> T cell-induced inflammatory cell death controls immune-evasive tumours
item.dc:creator: Bastian Kruse
Anthony C. Buzzai

Thomas Tüting

item.title: Silicon isotope constraints on terrestrial planet accretion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06135-z

The nucleosynthetic composition of silicon in meteorites indicates that material akin to early-formed differentiated asteroids must represent a major constituent of terrestrial planets such as Earth and Mars.
item.dc:title: Silicon isotope constraints on terrestrial planet accretion
item.dc:creator: Isaac J. Onyett
Martin Schiller
Georgy V. Makhatadze
Zhengbin Deng
Anders Johansen
Martin Bizzarro

item.title: Genome expansion by a CRISPR trimmer-integrase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06178-2

CRISPR systems lacking Cas4 can use fused or recruited exonucleases for faithful acquisition of new CRISPR immune sequences.
item.dc:title: Genome expansion by a CRISPR trimmer-integrase
item.dc:creator: Joy Y. Wang
Owen T. Tuck
Petr Skopintsev
Katarzyna M. Soczek
Gary Li
Basem Al-Shayeb
Julia Zhou
Jennifer A. Doudna

item.title: Concussion guidance for sports sidesteps brain-disease link — critics are baffled
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01964-4

The statement’s authors say that the connection between repeated head injuries and the condition CTE is based on data that is not rigorous enough.
item.dc:title: Concussion guidance for sports sidesteps brain-disease link — critics are baffled
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Quantum computer scales up by mitigating errors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01884-3

A post-processing technique for handling errors has enabled a quantum computer comprising 127 quantum bits to calculate the physical properties of a complex model system — a task that cannot be performed by a classical computer.
item.dc:title: Quantum computer scales up by mitigating errors
item.dc:creator: Göran Wendin
Jonas Bylander

item.title: Polio endgame finish is in sight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01773-9

Efforts to eradicate polio globally have been under way for more than 35 years. The development of modified versions of a vaccine in current use now makes eradication a real possibility.
item.dc:title: Polio endgame finish is in sight
item.dc:creator: Alan D. T. Barrett

item.title: How my bipolar diagnosis changed my scientific career
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01967-1

I spent more than a year in a manic state, burning out for the sake of my job. Here’s how I found balance again.
item.dc:title: How my bipolar diagnosis changed my scientific career
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kimple

item.title: Rice gene tamed using genome editing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01672-z

Genes in agricultural crops are usually fine-tuned through long periods of evolution and crop domestication. In a modern strategy to genetically improve crops, genome editing was used to rapidly develop a variant of a rice gene that shows promise for increasing the plant’s resistance to several diseases.
item.dc:title: Rice gene tamed using genome editing

item.title: A pangenome reference representative of 36 minority Chinese ethnic groups
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01675-w

In the first phase of its project to produce a genome reference that represents the genetic diversity of the people of China, the Chinese Pangenome Consortium analyse genomic sequences from 58 individuals representing 36 minority ethnic groups in China. The data capture genomic variability that is not currently reflected in human reference genomes.
item.dc:title: A pangenome reference representative of 36 minority Chinese ethnic groups

item.title: From tea to tofu: why Chinese dietary staples are rich pickings for research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01842-z

Public-health researchers are exploring the nutritional benefits of some familiar favourites of the Chinese table.
item.dc:title: From tea to tofu: why Chinese dietary staples are rich pickings for research
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: IBM quantum computer passes calculation milestone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01965-3

‘Benchmark’ experiment suggests quantum computers could have useful real-world applications within two years.
item.dc:title: IBM quantum computer passes calculation milestone
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How psychedelic drugs achieve their potent health benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01920-2

Mouse studies suggest that drugs from LSD to ecstasy renew the brain’s flexibility — but some scientists are sceptical.
item.dc:title: How psychedelic drugs achieve their potent health benefits
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Vaccine-derived polio is undermining the fight to eradicate the virus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01953-7

Wild polio has almost been eradicated, but vaccine-derived strains retain the potential to paralyse. Better vaccines have arrived — but they are only part of the answer.
item.dc:title: Vaccine-derived polio is undermining the fight to eradicate the virus

item.title: Nanoparticles containing diverse elements made using liquid metal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01793-5

The synthesis of high-entropy alloy nanoparticles (HEA-NPs) — small particles each containing multiple principal metal elements — typically requires extreme conditions to ensure adequate mixing of constituents. Innovative experiments show that the liquid metal can act as a mixing reservoir to facilitate the synthesis of a diverse range of such nanoparticles in mild conditions.
item.dc:title: Nanoparticles containing diverse elements made using liquid metal

item.title: Opening doors: how I crafted career opportunities abroad
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01968-0

Kokouvi Kassegne moved from Togo to China to pursue his passion for parasitology.
item.dc:title: Opening doors: how I crafted career opportunities abroad
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Timing is key for behavioural benefits of psychedelics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01869-2

Juvenile mice find social experiences more rewarding than do adults. The discovery that psychedelics can re-engage the social neural circuits for varying durations in adults points to a possible therapeutic mechanism for these drugs.
item.dc:title: Timing is key for behavioural benefits of psychedelics
item.dc:creator: Samuel C. Woodburn
Alex C. Kwan

item.title: Could endometriosis be caused by bacteria? Study offers fresh clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01956-4

Link to bacterial infection suggests a potential way to treat the painful disorder.
item.dc:title: Could endometriosis be caused by bacteria? Study offers fresh clues
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Nickel catalyses a host of chemical reactions in a general method
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01796-2

A minimal but general method has been developed for catalysing many different cross-coupling reactions — those in which two chemical fragments are joined. It requires only the two substrate substances, a nickel salt as a catalyst precursor, a catalyst for light-driven redox reactions and, in some cases, a nitrogen-containing base.
item.dc:title: Nickel catalyses a host of chemical reactions in a general method

item.dc:creator: Erica L. Satifka

item.title: A mitotic glue for shattered chromosomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01890-5

Two studies now shed light on how chromosomes that undergo catastrophic shattering are transmitted to daughter cells during cell division, thereby enabling them to be reassembled for the benefit of cancer cells.
item.dc:title: A mitotic glue for shattered chromosomes
item.dc:creator: Yibo Xue
Daniel Durocher

item.title: Mapping the Chinese microbiome: it’s time for a united effort
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Phosphate discovery hints at geochemistry and origin of Enceladus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01886-1

Evidence of phosphates in the subsurface ocean of Enceladus, an icy moon of Saturn, confirms that the water is alkaline. The finding provides clues about the geochemistry and origin of this moon and its ability to support life.
item.dc:title: Phosphate discovery hints at geochemistry and origin of Enceladus
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Yu. Zolotov

item.title: Daily briefing: Taurine makes animals live longer — but don’t binge on Red Bulls yet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01948-4

Big doses of an amino acid that is commonly used in energy drinks seem to help mice, worms and monkeys to live longer, healthier lives — but its effect is still unclear in people. Plus, reformatting papers is costing scientists millions.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Taurine makes animals live longer — but don’t binge on Red Bulls yet
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Taurine supplement makes animals live longer — what it means for people is unclear
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01910-4

The energy-drink ingredient offers striking health benefits in mice, monkeys and worms. But more work is needed to investigate its link with ageing.
item.dc:title: Taurine supplement makes animals live longer — what it means for people is unclear
